012package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;
013
014import java.sql.ResultSet;
015import java.sql.SQLException;
016
017import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLAction;
018import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLActions;
019import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
020
021/**
022 * Test that strings containing characters from all Unicode planes
023 * are passed between PG and Java without alteration (issue 21).
024 * <p>
025 * This function takes a string and an array of ints constructed in PG, such
026 * that PG believes the codepoints in the string to correspond exactly with the
027 * ints in the array. The function compares the two, generates a new array from
028 * the codepoints Java sees in the string and a new Java string from the
029 * original array, and returns a tuple (matched, cparray, s) where
030 * {@code matched} indicates whether the original array and string matched
031 * as seen by Java, and {@code cparray} and {@code s} are the new array and
032 * string generated in Java.
033 * <p>
034 * The supplied test query generates all Unicode code points 1k at a time,
035 * calls this function on each (1k array, 1k string) pair, and counts a failure
036 * if {@code matched} is false or the original and returned arrays or strings
037 * do not match as seen in SQL.
038 * <p>
039 * This example relies on {@code implementor} tags reflecting the PostgreSQL
040 * version, set up in the {@link ConditionalDDR} example, and also sets its own.
041 */
042@SQLActions({
043    @SQLAction(provides="postgresql_unicodetest",
044        implementor="postgresql_ge_90000", install=
045        "SELECT CASE" +
046        " WHEN 'UTF8' = current_setting('server_encoding')" +
047        " THEN set_config('pljava.implementors', 'postgresql_unicodetest,' ||" +
048        " current_setting('pljava.implementors'), true) " +
049        "END"
050    ),
051    @SQLAction(requires="unicodetest fn",
052    implementor="postgresql_unicodetest",
053    install=
054"   with " +
055"    usable_codepoints ( cp ) as ( " +
056"     select generate_series(1,x'd7ff'::int) " +
057"     union all " +
058"     select generate_series(x'e000'::int,x'10ffff'::int) " +
059"    ), " +
060"    test_inputs ( groupnum, cparray, s ) as ( " +
061"     select " +
062"       cp / 1024 as groupnum, " +
063"       array_agg(cp order by cp), string_agg(chr(cp), '' order by cp) " +
064"     from usable_codepoints " +
065"     group by groupnum " +
066"    ), " +
067"    test_outputs as ( " +
068"     select groupnum, cparray, s, unicodetest(s, cparray) as roundtrip " +
069"     from test_inputs " +
070"    ), " +
071"    test_failures as ( " +
072"     select * " +
073"     from test_outputs " +
074"     where " +
075"      cparray != (roundtrip).cparray or s != (roundtrip).s " +
076"      or not (roundtrip).matched " +
077"    ), " +
078"    test_summary ( n_failing_groups, first_failing_group ) as ( " +
079"     select count(*), min(groupnum) from test_failures " +
080"    ) " +
081"   select " +
082"    case when n_failing_groups > 0 then " +
083"     javatest.logmessage('WARNING', n_failing_groups || " +
084"      ' 1k codepoint ranges had mismatches, first is block starting 0x' || " +
085"      to_hex(1024 * first_failing_group)) " +
086"    else " +
087"     javatest.logmessage('INFO', " +
088"        'all Unicode codepoint ranges roundtripped successfully.') " +
089"    end " +
090"    from test_summary"
091    ),
092    @SQLAction(
093        install=
094            "CREATE TYPE unicodetestrow AS " +
095            "(matched boolean, cparray integer[], s text)",
096        remove="DROP TYPE unicodetestrow",
097        provides="unicodetestrow type"
098    )
099})
100public class UnicodeRoundTripTest {
101    /**
102     * This function takes a string and an array of ints constructed in PG,
103     * such that PG believes the codepoints in the string to correspond exactly
104     * with the ints in the array. The function compares the two, generates a
105     * new array from the codepoints Java sees in the string and a new Java
106     * string from the original array, and returns a tuple (matched, cparray,
107     * s) where {@code matched} indicates whether the original array and string
108     * matched as seen by Java, and {@code cparray} and {@code s} are the new
109     * array and string generated in Java.
110     *
111     * @param s A string, whose codepoints should match the entries of
112     *        {@code ints}
113     * @param ints Array of ints that should match the codepoints in {@code s}
114     * @param rs OUT (matched, cparray, s) as described above
115     * @return true to indicate the OUT tuple is not null
116     */
117    @Function(type="unicodetestrow",
118        requires="unicodetestrow type", provides="unicodetest fn")
119    public static boolean unicodetest(String s, int[] ints, ResultSet rs)
120    throws SQLException {
121        boolean ok = true;
122
123        int cpc = s.codePointCount(0, s.length());
124        Integer[] myInts = new Integer[cpc];
125        int ci = 0;
126        for ( int cpi = 0; cpi < cpc; cpi++ ) {
127            myInts[cpi] = s.codePointAt(ci);
128            ci = s.offsetByCodePoints(ci, 1);
129        }
130
131        String myS = new String(ints, 0, ints.length);
132
133        if ( ints.length != myInts.length )
134            ok = false;
135        else
136            for ( int i = 0; i < ints.length; ++ i )
137    if ( ints[i] != myInts[i] )
138        ok = false;
139
140        rs.updateBoolean("matched", ok);
141        rs.updateObject("cparray", myInts);
142        rs.updateString("s", myS);
143        return true;
144    }
145}
